path_1.title: Matrix Revolutions, The (2003)
path_1.feeling: Visually bold but emotionally flat and overblown compared to the thoughtful sci-fi I prefer.

path_1.title: Bug's Life, A (1998)
path_1.feeling: Charming and inventive, but it never hit me on a deeper level.

path_1.title: Nightmare Before Christmas, The (1993)
path_1.feeling: Macabre whimsy and craft won me over despite the musical trappings.

path_1.title: Hugo (2011)
path_1.feeling: A lovely ode to cinema that warms more than it thrills me.

path_1.title: Pulp Fiction (1994)
path_1.feeling: Electric dialogue and braided crime tales right in my sweet spot.

path_1.title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)
path_1.feeling: A gripping, bleak spiral of consequence that sticks to the ribs.

path_1.title: Indie Game: The Movie (2012)
path_1.feeling: Intimate, honest look at creation that resonated with my love for process.

path_1.title: Diving Bell and the Butterfly, The (Scaphandre et le papillon, Le) (2007)
path_1.feeling: Lyrical and deeply humane, it quietly wrecked me.

path_1.title: Evil Dead, The (1981)
path_1.feeling: Inventive and scrappy, fun more than truly unsettling for me.

path_1.title: 13 Tzameti (2005)
path_1.feeling: Brutal, lean tension that had me clenched the whole way.

path_1.title: The Autopsy of Jane Doe (2016)
path_1.feeling: Claustrophobic dread done right, with mystery that pays off in mood.

path_1.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_1.feeling: Relentless and sickening in the best way, a crime horror that lingers.

path_1.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_1.feeling: Romantic high-concept sci-fi that charms without losing momentum.

path_1.title: Arrival (2016)
path_1.feeling: Intimate, mind-expanding science fiction that hits heart and head.

path_1.title: 10 Cloverfield Lane (2016)
path_1.feeling: Nerve-jangling chamber piece with just enough ambiguity to haunt me.

path_1.title: Nymphomaniac: Volume II (2013)
path_1.feeling: Unflinching and jagged

path_1.title: Saving Private Ryan (1998)
path_1.feeling: Viscerally powerful, less meditative than my favorite war films but still outstanding.

path_1.title: Match Point (2005)
path_1.feeling: Cold, precise morality play that satisfied my taste for tense unraveling.

path_1.title: Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind (Kaze no tani no Naushika) (1984)
path_1.feeling: Sweeping, soulful eco-fantasy with stakes and heart I can feel.

path_1.title: Slither (2006)
path_1.feeling: Gooey, witty creature-feature fun that scratches my horror itch.

path_1.title: Lawless (2012)
path_1.feeling: Gritty and atmospheric, even if it plays familiar notes.

path_1.title: Gangs of New York (2002)
path_1.feeling: Grand and savage, impressive more than immersive for me.

path_1.title: L.A. Confidential (1997)
path_1.feeling: Slick neo-noir perfection with characters and turns I savor.

path_1.title: Welcome to the Dollhouse (1995)
path_1.feeling: Painfully funny and unflinching, right in my awkward-human wheelhouse.

path_1.title: Hell in the Pacific (1968)
path_1.feeling: Spare, tense survival study that earns its quiet.

path_1.title: Tucker & Dale vs Evil (2010)
path_1.feeling: Smart, good-hearted splatstick that toys with horror tropes I love.

path_1.title: Headhunters (Hodejegerne) (2011)
path_1.feeling: Razor-edged, twisty crime thriller that kept me grinning and wincing.

path_2.title: Matrix Revolutions, The (2003)
path_2.feeling: Effects-heavy endgame with blunted philosophy leaves me cold

path_2.title: Bug's Life, A (1998)
path_2.feeling: Charming and brisk but too featherweight for my darker leanings

path_2.title: Nightmare Before Christmas, The (1993)
path_2.feeling: Macabre whimsy and handcrafted mood win me over despite the songs

path_2.title: Hugo (2011)
path_2.feeling: Gentle cinephile reverie with enough melancholy to keep me engaged

path_2.title: Pulp Fiction (1994)
path_2.feeling: Sardonic, violent riffs on fate and chance hit my crime sweet spot

path_2.title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)
path_2.feeling: A bleak, spiraling family-crime tragedy that tightens like a noose

path_2.title: Indie Game: The Movie (2012)
path_2.feeling: Creative obsession and anxiety portrayed with an intimacy I respond to

path_2.title: Diving Bell and the Butterfly, The (Scaphandre et le papillon, Le) (2007)
path_2.feeling: Lyrical confinement that haunts with quiet dread and resilience

path_2.title: Evil Dead, The (1981)
path_2.feeling: Scrappy splatter charm, but I crave a heavier, more suffocating menace

path_2.title: 13 Tzameti (2005)
path_2.feeling: Stripped-down fatalism and tension that knot my stomach

path_2.title: The Autopsy of Jane Doe (2016)
path_2.feeling: Claustrophobic mystery and escalating dread squarely in my wheelhouse

path_2.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_2.feeling: Methodical nihilism and rain-soaked doom exactly my tempo

path_2.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_2.feeling: Fate-versus-choice romance with a propulsive, heady thriller pulse

path_2.title: Arrival (2016)
path_2.feeling: Somber, cerebral awe fused with human ache—this is my oxygen

path_2.title: 10 Cloverfield Lane (2016)
path_2.feeling: Bottled paranoia and control games I hungrily devour

path_2.title: Nymphomaniac: Volume II (2013)
path_2.feeling: Provocative, bleak confession that I respect more than I love

path_2.title: Saving Private Ryan (1998)
path_2.feeling: Visceral and harrowing, though I prefer a more meditative war rumination

path_2.title: Match Point (2005)
path_2.feeling: Cold-blooded ambition and chance unravel into satisfying moral rot

path_2.title: Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind (Kaze no tani no Naushika) (1984)
path_2.feeling: Earnest eco-myth with weight and melancholy that linger

path_2.title: Slither (2006)
path_2.feeling: Gooey, witty creature chaos that amuses more than it unnerves

path_2.title: Lawless (2012)
path_2.feeling: Gritty, mournful bootlegger noir that fits my crime tastes

path_2.title: Gangs of New York (2002)
path_2.feeling: Brutal and operatic but too sprawling for my preference

path_2.title: L.A. Confidential (1997)
path_2.feeling: Sleek, ruthless noir that scratches my itch for bleak crime

path_2.title: Welcome to the Dollhouse (1995)
path_2.feeling: Cruel, awkward adolescence with the sting and empathy I gravitate toward

path_2.title: Hell in the Pacific (1968)
path_2.feeling: Sparse, moral survival duel that lets silence do the bruising

path_2.title: Tucker & Dale vs Evil (2010)
path_2.feeling: Clever genre flip that entertains even if it softens the dread

path_2.title: Headhunters (Hodejegerne) (2011)
path_2.feeling: Slick, nasty twists that keep me taut and uneasy

path_2.title: Matrix Revolutions, The (2003)
path_2.feeling: Big, clangy mech-war spectacle that drowns the ideas I care about.

path_2.title: Bug's Life, A (1998)
path_2.feeling: Cute and competent, but featherlight stakes and humor are far from my lane.

path_2.title: Nightmare Before Christmas, The (1993)
path_2.feeling: Gothic whimsy and immaculate craft I admire even if the sing-song sweetness keeps me at arm’s length.

path_2.title: Hugo (2011)
path_2.feeling: A warm, lovingly crafted ode to cinema that soothes more than it obsesses me.

path_2.title: Pulp Fiction (1994)
path_2.feeling: A gleefully nasty, propulsive crime mosaic that hits my dark-humor sweet spot.

path_2.title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)
path_2.feeling: A bruising, spiraling family heist tragedy with the bleak moral fallout I savor.

path_2.title: Indie Game: The Movie (2012)
path_2.feeling: Intimate, obsessive creative struggle that engages me even without the darkness I usually chase.

path_2.title: Diving Bell and the Butterfly, The (Scaphandre et le papillon, Le) (2007)
path_2.feeling: Luminous, suffocating empathy that left me quietly wrecked.

path_2.title: Evil Dead, The (1981)
path_2.feeling: Inventive, scrappy splatter I respect more than I fear.

path_2.title: 13 Tzameti (2005)
path_2.feeling: Lean, pitiless descent that tightens around the throat exactly how I like.

path_2.title: The Autopsy of Jane Doe (2016)
path_2.feeling: Claustrophobic, escalating dread with a great procedural hook.

path_2.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_2.feeling: Relentlessly grim and methodical in a way that still crawls under my skin.

path_2.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_2.feeling: Romance laced with paranoid sci-fi clockwork that goes down smooth for me.

path_2.title: Arrival (2016)
path_2.feeling: A contemplative, humane first-contact puzzle that devastates me.

path_2.title: 10 Cloverfield Lane (2016)
path_2.feeling: Airless, psychologically barbed captivity thriller that hums with menace.

path_2.title: Nymphomaniac: Volume II (2013)
path_2.feeling: Bleak, abrasive confession that fascinates even as it keeps me at an icy remove.

path_2.title: Saving Private Ryan (1998)
path_2.feeling: Visceral and effective, though its sentimentality softens the existential chill I crave.

path_2.title: Match Point (2005)
path_2.feeling: A cold-blooded morality play whose quiet rot and inevitability I relish.

path_2.title: Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind (Kaze no tani no Naushika) (1984)
path_2.feeling: Rich, empathetic world-building I admire more than I feel in my bones.

path_2.title: Slither (2006)
path_2.feeling: Goopy, jokey creature mayhem that amuses without burrowing under my skin.

path_2.title: Lawless (2012)
path_2.feeling: Solid, mournful outlaw tale with enough grit and fatalism to pull me in.

path_2.feeling: Brutal and grand, but the bloat dilutes the bleak precision I prefer.

path_2.feeling: Acidic coming-of-age cruelty that stings, even if it is not quite my obsession.

path_5.feeling: Idea-rich, tender sci-fi that left me awed and aching.

path_5.title: 10 Cloverfield Lane (2016)
path_5.feeling: Airtight bunker tension with character bite, exactly my kind of thriller.

path_5.title: Nymphomaniac: Volume II (2013)
path_5.feeling: A bruising, self-lacerating spiral with flashes of insight that felt more punishing than profound for me.

path_5.title: Saving Private Ryan (1998)
path_5.feeling: Harrowing, humane war spectacle that gave me the weight I crave even if the sentiment sometimes shows.

path_5.title: Match Point (2005)
path_5.feeling: An icy, morally queasy climb and fall that scratched my itch for fate, guilt, and consequence.

path_5.title: Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind (Kaze no tani no Naushika) (1984)
path_5.feeling: Rapturous eco-fantasy with soul and scope that stirred me.

path_5.title: Slither (2006)
path_5.feeling: Gooey creature-feature fun where the jokes sometimes undercut the dread I want.

path_5.title: Lawless (2012)
path_5.feeling: A bristling backwoods crime tale with enough menace and melancholy to satisfy.

path_5.title: Gangs of New York (2002)
path_5.feeling: A bruised, operatic revenge saga whose mood and grit win out over its bloat.

path_5.title: L.A. Confidential (1997)
path_5.feeling: Sleek, bruised noir with moral rot and momentum that gripped me hard.

path_5.title: Welcome to the Dollhouse (1995)
path_5.feeling: Painfully funny, empathetic suburban cruelty that hit close without quite crushing me.

path_5.title: Hell in the Pacific (1968)
path_5.feeling: A lean, mostly wordless war parable with the existential mood and human weight I love.

path_5.title: Tucker & Dale vs Evil (2010)
path_5.feeling: A clever genre flip with real charm, though the goofiness keeps it light on mood and menace.

path_5.title: Headhunters (Hodejegerne) (2011)
path_5.feeling: A twisty, propulsive cat-and-mouse that delivered the lean menace I look for.

path_5.title: Matrix Revolutions, The (2003)
path_5.feeling: Spectacle-heavy climax with flashes of awe, but light on the philosophical chill and character focus I crave.

path_5.title: Bug's Life, A (1998)
path_5.feeling: Charming colony caper—pleasant, but too pat and polished to linger for me.

path_5.title: Nightmare Before Christmas, The (1993)
path_5.feeling: Macabre whimsy and melancholy craft worked on me, even if the songs soften the bite.

path_5.title: Hugo (2011)
path_5.feeling: Cine-love and clockwork heart—handsome, earnest, and quietly moving.

path_5.title: Pulp Fiction (1994)
path_5.feeling: Twisty, talky crime mosaic brimming with menace and wit—cool and propulsive.

path_5.title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)
path_5.feeling: Bleak, morally rotted family spiral that pressed all my tension-and-empathy buttons.

path_5.title: Indie Game: The Movie (2012)
path_5.feeling: Intimate, nervy creative crucible that scratched my process-obsessed itch.

path_5.title: Diving Bell and the Butterfly, The (Scaphandre et le papillon, Le) (2007)
path_5.feeling: Luminous, intimate survival of mind and memory—quietly devastating.

path_5.title: Evil Dead, The (1981)
path_5.feeling: Grotty cabin nightmare with scrappy zeal—fun, if light on the atmosphere I crave.

path_5.title: 13 Tzameti (2005)
path_5.feeling: Lean, nerve-shredding descent into moral chaos—right up my alley.

path_5.title: The Autopsy of Jane Doe (2016)
path_5.feeling: Cold, clinical dread anchored by a tender father-son core—moody and gripping.

path_5.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_5.feeling: A relentlessly brutal true-crime ordeal with grim moral weight—compelling and hard to shake.

path_5.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_5.feeling: Fate-bending romance with paranoid snap that hit my sci-fi/heart sweet spot.

path_5.title: Arrival (2016)
path_5.feeling: Humane, idea-rich wonder with melancholy weight—exactly my sci-fi sweet spot.

path_5.title: 10 Cloverfield Lane (2016)
path_5.feeling: Claustrophobic menace with character heft—my kind of contained thriller.

path_5.title: Nymphomaniac: Volume II (2013)
path_5.feeling: Provocative and punishing, engaging ideas but the cruelty keeps me at a distance.

path_5.title: Saving Private Ryan (1998)
path_5.feeling: Brutal, visceral hero’s errand with real weight—moving, if less meditative than I crave.

path_5.title: Match Point (2005)
path_5.feeling: Icy ambition and moral rot in a slow-burn that suits my taste.

path_5.title: Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind (Kaze no tani no Naushika) (1984)
path_5.feeling: Sweeping, humane eco-fantasy with real soul and stakes—gorgeous and stirring.

path_5.feeling: Gooey creature mayhem—fun, but the jokey tone blunts the menace for me.

path_5.feeling: Gritty backwoods crime saga with enough menace and melancholy to satisfy.

path_5.feeling: Operatic and bruising, but the sprawl mutes the intimacy I crave.

path_5.feeling: Sleek, morally filthy noir that hits my sweet spot for menace and character.
